items.message:
This Flood alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

Monday morning's tide at 07:15 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with south-easterly force 8 winds and large waves.
Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 07:15 AM and 12:15 PM on 21/11/2022.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 22/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Monday morning's tide at 05:00 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with south-easterly force 8 winds and large waves.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour.
Flooding is possible at Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour between 09:30 AM and 10:15 AM on 21/11/2022.

The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 22/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Passfield Mill and Godalming areas.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. It is forecast to be a wet day with some potential heavy rainfall in places.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of further rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to begin rising at midday today 21/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.   
  
This message will be updated by 14:00 this afternoon, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Monday morning's tide at 11:15 AM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with south-easterly force 7 winds and large waves.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
We are expecting further unsettled weather which will may mean similar impacts for the next high tide tomorrow morning.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
Flooding is possible at Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle from 11:00 AM on 21/11/2022.
Weather conditions are expected to produce large onshore waves.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
This message will be updated by 06:00 PM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar continue to broadly fall. Whilst the river level at Alverstone is rising slightly in response to the small amount of overnight rainfall, the Eastern Yar at Sandown continues to fall and is now below the level at which Fort Holiday Park is affected. Operation of Bembridge sluices, over the period of Neap tides, has reduced water levels within Brading Marshes and effectively managed the risk of property flooding in Brading. The current weather forecast indicates showers may affect the Eastern Yar catchment this afternoon but only small totals of rain are forecast. Tomorrow morning (21/11/22), a frontal band of rain will potentially bring up to 25mm of rain. This will be followed by showers Monday evening into Tuesday morning (22/11/22), possibly adding an additional 10mm of rain. If realised, this would likely see a Flood Alert issued for the Eastern Yar and potentially Flood Warnings covering the upper and lower Eastern Yar catchment. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water.

items.description: Windle Brook and Hale, Mill and Addlestone Bournes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Addlestone Bourne.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today. It is forecast to be a wet day with some potential heavy rainfall in places.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 21/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, but has fallen from its peak of last Thursday. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. 5mm of rain has already fallen Monday morning, with another 10mm of rain predicted Monday afternoon. More rain is forecast most days this week. River levels will rise again Monday afternoon and evening, before beginning to fall by 04:00 Tuesday 22/11/2022. By the end of the week, river levels could be higher than last week. In Barnham, only minimal impacts are currently expected, with river levels comparatively lower. We continue to monitor the situation and routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 22/11/2022.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
River levels are rising at the  Beggearn Huish river gauge due to rainfall overnight.
Areas most at risk include the River Washford.
River levels will be at their highest between midday and 19:00 on Monday 21/11/2022. There is further rainfall forecast on Tuesday but this will be less intense than today.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 22/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92 m and is stable.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.13m and is rising by approximately 11mm 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Pumping will begin at Episcopi pumping station when levels in the river allow.

Dry weather is forecast for today Thursday, 17/11/2022, with the risk of isolated showers.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated at 12:00 on Friday, 18/11/2022.

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from Monday morning 21st November.

The persistent frontal rain during Monday morning will clear the area from midday, leaving showery conditions throughout the rest of today.  

River levels will continue to rise throughout Monday morning and will be at their highest during Monday afternoon. Levels will remain high and there is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.   

We expect the river to remain high throughout today. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Tuesday morning or earlier if the situation changes

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
River levels are falling at the Blandford, Throop, Wimborne A31 gauge.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River Ouse levels are continuing to fall following recent higher levels resulting from rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible on riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and Naburn, particularly around Naburn Lock. River levels have also peaked at Naburn and will continue to fall slowly. Tidal levels are not currently of concern. Further rainfall is expected later today, and river levels may fluctuate further, remaining high on Monday (21/11/2022). The Foss Barrier is no longer in operation. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We anticipate being able to remove this alert later today. Nevertheless, this message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River Ouse levels are continuing to fall following recent higher levels resulting from rainfall on 17/11/2022. Flooding remains possible on riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York, particularly around Kings Staith and Queens Staith. Some further rainfall is expected later today, and river levels may fluctuate further, remaining high on Monday (21/11/2022). The Foss Barrier is no longer in operation. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We anticipate being able to remove this alert later today. Nevertheless, this message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton today, Monday 21/11/2022. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall over the last few days. Flooding remains possible in locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around local roads and low-lying land around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington through the weekend. River levels will remain high on Monday 21/11/2022 but are falling slowly. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The weather forecast for today is for dry spells with scattered showers. Further rainfall, some of which could be heavy, is forecast for Monday. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are still high on the River Cherwell but are starting to stabilise. The risk of flooding of roads and farmland remains, especially in the Thrupp area.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast today. River levels are stabilising but are sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 21/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
